speaker: Dan
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Dan and joining me today is Neil. Hi Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: Hi there, Dan.

speaker: Dan
text: You're a married man, Neil. When you were wed, did your wife change her family name?

speaker: Neil
text: Yes she did.

speaker: Dan
text: Was that her choice?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes. She didn't like her old name, so for her it was a win-win. How about you?

speaker: Dan
text: Well, my wife wanted to keep her surname, but was forced to adopt mine because that was the law where we got married.

speaker: Neil
text: Would you have thought about taking her name?

speaker: Dan
text: That's what we're talking about in this 6 Minute English. A husband taking a wife's name after marriage. All that, six related words and our quiz question.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Let's have the question.

speaker: Dan
text: In which country has it been forbidden since 1789 for a citizen to change their name legally, even after marriage?

speaker: Dan
text: a) Japan

speaker: Dan
text: b) France

speaker: Dan
text: c) Turkey

speaker: Neil
text: I'm going to go for b) France

speaker: maiden name
text: And we'll see if you're right later. Now, traditionally in the UK, when a man and a woman get married, the woman takes the man's family name. And this replaces her maiden name.

speaker: Neil
text: A maiden name is the surname a woman had before she was married. This all dates back to the Norman invasion of England, back in 1066. They introduced the idea that when a woman married a man, she became his property. As a result of this, she took his name.

speaker: double-barrelled
text: These days, many women elect to keep their maiden name upon marriage or combine it with their new husband's in some way, sometimes by making the name double-barrelled.

speaker: Neil
text: A double-barrelled name is two names that are connected by a hyphen, such as Jones-Smith.

speaker: Dan
text: However, a growing number of couples in western culture are doing it differently . When they get married, the husband elects to take the wife's surname.

speaker: Neil
text: In a BBC article about surnames and marriage, Rory Dearlove, formerly Rory Cook, talks about why he decided to take his wife's surname. He said that he wasn't really attached to his name anyway. To him it didn't make any difference.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, he's not alone. A recent study of 2000 UK adults by Opinium, a strategic insight agency, suggested that one in ten millennial men, currently between 18 and 34 years old, fall into this category.

speaker: patriarchal
text: Charlie Shaw, a Tibetan Buddhist meditation instructor, who took his wife's name when they married last year, said that it was an opportunity to acknowledge the unseen patriarchal bias and sexism in our society.

speaker: bias
text: Patriarchal means 'controlled by men' and a bias is the unfair support or opposition to a person, thing or idea.

speaker: Neil
text: Many traditional societies were patriarchal. But modern UK society is less like that. Everyone is meant to be equal.

speaker: wear the trousers
text: Ah yes, but that's the unseen part. And there's the social view of things too. Rachel Robnett, a researcher at the University of Nevada surveyed a number of people in the US and UK, and found that the husbands of women who keep their maiden names are viewed as 'feminine', while the women are believed to 'wear the trousers'.

speaker: Neil
text: If you 'wear the trousers' in a relationship, it means you 'have the control and make the decisions for both people'.

speaker: Dan
text: I wondered about that, so I went out into London and asked people what they thought about a man who took his wife's name when they got married. Here's what they said.

speaker: Woman
text: I don't think it's a bad idea at all. My dad's 55 and he took my mother's surname. If people want to do it, then all the power to them.

speaker: Man
text: It's each to their own really. It doesn't hurt anybody. And it's no different from a woman taking a man's name.

speaker: Woman
text: The only reason I think that anybody should take someone else's surname if just for the creation of a family unit. But if it's just out of principle, I don't agree.

speaker: Dan
text: It seems that the people I talked to are comfortable with the idea.

speaker: unit
text: Yes. Most said that people are free to do what they want. One woman even mentioned the creation of a family unit.

speaker: Dan
text: A unit is a group of people living or working together. A typical family unit would be two parents and some children. Well, that answers that question. People don't seem to mind who takes who's name.

speaker: Neil
text: Speaking of questions. How about our quiz question?

speaker: Dan
text: Oh yes, I asked you in which country it's been forbidden since 1789 for a citizen to change their name legally, even after marriage?

speaker: Dan
text: a) Japan

speaker: Dan
text: b) France

speaker: Dan
text: c) Turkey

speaker: Neil
text: And I said b)France

speaker: Dan
text: And you were spot on as usual, Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: Let's take a look at the vocabulary, shall we?

speaker: maiden name
text: First we had maiden name. This is a woman's family name before she is married. My mother refused to give up her maiden name to my father when she got married.

speaker: double-barrelled
text: Then we had double-barrelled. A double-barrelled name is two names that are joined by a hyphen. Can you think of any famous examples?

speaker: patriarchal
text: Well, there's the Duchess of Cornwall Camilla Parker-Bowles for one. She's married to Prince Charles – next in line to the English throne. Then we had patriarchal. If something is patriarchal, it is controlled by men. The feminine equivalent is matriarchal, controlled by women.

speaker: bias
text: Then we had bias. A bias is unfair support or opposition to a person, thing or idea.

speaker: wear the trousers
text: Many fans are biased in favour of their football team. Then we had wear the trousers. If you wear the trousers, you have the control and make the decisions for both people. Do you wear the trousers in your marriage, Neil?

speaker: unit
text: Oh, we both wear the trousers in my marriage, thank you Dan. Then we had unit. A unit is a group of people living or working together. Like the BBC Learning English team… or unit!

speaker: Dan
